Simulated data
1 parent dataset, 30 final samples
All simulated samples were created from a dataset available in R through the SeuratData package. The interferon-treated PBMC dataset was selected as it contains case and control data already intergrated into a single object with cell annotations.
# IFNB-Stimulated & Control PBMC data
library(SeuratData)
InstallData("ifnb")
data("ifnb")
ifnb <- UpdateSeuratObject(ifnb)
These foundational simulated samples were altered by randomly extracting a fixed percentage of their cells (2.5, 5, 10, 15, or 20), passing them through a damage-pertubration function, and reintroducing them to the sample. The resulting datasets are available for download on Zenodo, .

title: Overview
text:
Filtering cells that have lost transcriptomic information during isolation protocols, referred to here as “damaged cells”, is a fundamental quality control task for single cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) data analysis. However, unlike other aspects of cell quality control, such as doublet and empty droplet removal, how to best filter damaged cells from single cell data has not been thoroughly explored.
Searching online tutorials, forums, and published articles will bring you to the same conclusion: filter cells that express a high proportion of mitochondrial genes. This is because damaged cells are understood to have impaired membranes where cytoplasmic RNA content has escaped. It is for the same reason that the number of unique transcripts and UMIs per cell are also recommended metrics for identifying damaged cells.
More recently, the proportion of unspliced RNA, targeting transcripts that remain intact in the nucleus in the event of damage, and ribosomal RNA, targeting those that do not, are offered as damaged cell quality control metrics. Extending from this, the expression of the nuclear-located long non-coding RNA, MALAT1, has also been suggested as a potential metric for identifying damaged cells.
The problem for a user then arises in two forms: 1. Which cell quality controls metrics should I use and 2. According to what outlier detection framework should I perform filtering
Damaged cell detection tools provide their own solutions to the problems. However, the relative effectiveness of these tools, and of manual methods, is yet to be systematically determined. Our goal with this benchmark is to provide an objective answer to the question of how to best filter damaged cells in single cell data. Providing users with information on the characteristics of each available strategy, we aim for comprehensive, robust action towards addressing this quality control task.

But searching for true damaged droplets in a sample-specific manner is tedious and not always intuitive, leading to user-defined filtering that lacks reproducibility.
The analysis is made up of four components beginning with a search for manual and tool-based strategies for damaged cell filtering, A. To test the strategies, data was collected and processed, B, for testing and comparison, C. An overview of the results are condensed, D, into sections for the user, containing usage recommendations, and the developers, containing areas for improvement.

title: Contribute
text:
The results of our benchmark (Damage Bench, link) offer a static view of the current landscape of damaged cell detection. As new strategies emerge, and new ground truth datasets become available, we intend for them to be added to our benchmarking framework.
If you can offer a novel strategy, metric to benchmarking the strategies, or dataset, please think of contributing.

title: Results
text: Explore the current consensus results below. To change the preferred ranking system, select an option from the Rank button. If you wish to change the strategies viewed, select an option from the View button.

title: Benchmark
text:
Article: https://doi.org/10.1186/s13059-021-02547-0
  
Identifies damaged cells within sample-specific clusters using the Louvain algorithm for clustering and MAD-based univariate outlier detection of UMI, feature counts, and mitochondrial or ribosomal percentages.
Tutorial



Article: https://doi.org/10.1186/s13059-022-02820-w
  
Uses nuclear fraction (ratio of unspliced to spliced transcripts) and UMI counts with an Expectation-Maximization model to classify damaged cells.
Tutorial



Article: https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-030-26969-2_47
  
Combines multiple quality control measures to detect damaged cells, focusing on ensemble-based metrics



Article: https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1009290
  
Applies a mixture model to mitochondrial percentage and library complexity to assign posterior probabilities for identifying damaged cells.
Tutorial



Article: https://doi.org/10.1186/s13059-023-02859-3
  
Automates sample-wide multivariate outlier detection using robust Mahalanobis distances for mitochondrial, ribosomal, and UMI counts.
Tutorial



Article: https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btw777
  
Provides diagnostic visualizations and filtering functions to assess and remove damaged cells using user-defined thresholds
Tutorial



Article: https://doi.org/10.1101/2023.02.07.526574

 
Detects apoptotic cells using scaled and transformed QC features with logistic regression and cross-validation for soft labeling.








This involves setting a fixed value for mitochondrial percent expression above which cells are classified as damaged. Implementation of this method varies based on preferred platform, for example using default functions in the Seurat R package,

data[["percent.mt"]] <- PercentageFeatureSet(data, pattern = "^MT-")
data <- subset(data, subset = percent.mt < 10)

And the Scanpy python package,

data.var['mt'] = data.var_names.str.startswith('MT-')
sc.pp.calculate_qc_metrics(data, qc_vars=['mt'], percent_top=None, log1p=False, inplace=True)
data = data[data.obs.pct_counts_mt < 10, :]
